texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Public clouds are the all-you-can-eat buffet of infrastructure. Nearly any IT problem can be solved in minutes with a few clicks or API requests.
texts.text: Public clouds are the all-you-can-eat buffet of infrastructure. Nearly any IT problem can be solved in minutes with a few clicks or API requests.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is not your average buffet.
texts.text: This is not your average buffet.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every item at the buffet comes with a cost. Many of these costs are difficult to understand. Even if you do understand them, estimating your potential usage of these services is challenging.
texts.text: Every item at the buffet comes with a cost. Many of these costs are difficult to understand. Even if you do understand them, estimating your potential usage of these services is challenging.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most services are pay-per-use where you pay based on the time used or the amount used. Other charges are one-time costs that get billed immediately.
texts.text: Most services are pay-per-use where you pay based on the time used or the amount used. Other charges are one-time costs that get billed immediately.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some pricing, like object storage, looks totally straightforward at first glance. Then you find millions upon millions of half penny charges that add up to real money.
texts.text: Some pricing, like object storage, looks totally straightforward at first glance. Then you find millions upon millions of half penny charges that add up to real money.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Then there's the situation that angers me the most: charges for infrastructure you deployed and forgot to clean up!
texts.text: Then there's the situation that angers me the most: charges for infrastructure you deployed and forgot to clean up!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: How do we tackle this problem? Let's get right to it.
texts.text: How do we tackle this problem? Let's get right to it.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Set a budget
texts.text: Set a budget

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: AWS allows you to set a budget and get alarms when you've consumed part of your budget or exceeded it entirely. This is a great way to catch unexpected charges. It also helps you find forgotten deployments.
texts.text: AWS allows you to set a budget and get alarms when you've consumed part of your budget or exceeded it entirely. This is a great way to catch unexpected charges. It also helps you find forgotten deployments.

texts.orig: Head on over to the  AWS Billing Dashboard  first. Look for  Budgets  on the left navigation menu and click it.

texts.orig: My actual storage consumption costs were quite low, but my tier 1 and 2 requests increased massively. I began sifting through my scripts that do things in S3. texts.label: title
texts.orig: Remember the forgotten
texts.text: Remember the forgotten

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As I mentioned earlier, one of the most painful situations involves big charges for infrastructure that you forgot about. Perhaps it's an EC2 instance you spun up for testing. Maybe it's a Lambda you tried and forgot about. Perhaps you provisioned a NAT gateway  (ultimate pain) .
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, one of the most painful situations involves big charges for infrastructure that you forgot about. Perhaps it's an EC2 instance you spun up for testing. Maybe it's a Lambda you tried and forgot about. Perhaps you provisioned a NAT gateway  (ultimate pain) .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Monitoring your budgets will help a lot with forgotten infrastructure, but you only find out  after  your bill increased.
texts.text: Monitoring your budgets will help a lot with forgotten infrastructure, but you only find out  after  your bill increased.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of my mistakes happen with EC2-related infrastructure such as instances, volumes, or snapshots. EC2 is a region-specific service, though. Who wants to go through their EC2 infrastructure region by region?
texts.text: Most of my mistakes happen with EC2-related infrastructure such as instances, volumes, or snapshots. EC2 is a region-specific service, though. Who wants to go through their EC2 infrastructure region by region?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, AWS provides the  EC2 Global View . You get a look across all of your EC2 infrastructure in all regions to get counds of instances, networks, volumes, and auto scaling groups. This page helped me find some forgotten snapshots that kept dinging me with small bills each month.

texts.orig: Plan ahead for costs

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Storing your terraform code in a GitHub repository allows you to make pull requests for changes and see what will change. You can  run terraform via GitHub Actions .
texts.text: Storing your terraform code in a GitHub repository allows you to make pull requests for changes and see what will change. You can  run terraform via GitHub Actions .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you have that running, consider adding  Infracost  to your repository. Infracost analyzes each pull request and explains the billing changes based on what you're deploying (or destroying). It replies in the PR with a comment detailing the potential charges that your change might incur.
